The SanDisk Extreme Pro CompactFlash Memory Card brings our fastest data speed and expansive capacities to your DSLR camera or HD camcorder. Equipped with SanDisk's latest memory technologies, this memory card is the professional's choice. for more info: http://tinyurl.com/cz9wlp6﻿

Pelican 0945 Compact Flash Case ( in stock ) price : 260 EGP
Keep your compact flash memory cards safe and secure with the Pelican compact flash memory card storage and protector case. Store up to 4 compact flash memory cards in a single case.﻿
Meer weergevenMinder weergeven · Vertalen

Big cards vs. Many small cards 128GB CF for $170 64GB COMPACT FLASH FOR $85
One of the many arguments/religions of serious photographers is whether to use many small memory cards (these days 8gb or 16gb) or a few big cards.
Today Amazon is having a sale on 128GB compact flash and 64gb compact flash made by brand name Lexar (tho they are 400x rather than the fastest 1000x) http://www.amazon.com/gp/goldbox/discussion/A255GY6XQM6GKK/ref=cm_sw_r_tw_gb_eSE3qb0RN6FEN
Here's my take on the big vs. small cards
MISSING A SHOT vs. SMALL CHANCE OF LOSING ALL SHOTS Murphy's law guarantees your memory card will be empty at the critical moment. Any time you are shooting action you have the chance to miss the decisive moment. Yes, can change the card early but then you need that many more small cards and increase your risk of losing one.
Statistically, if you have 1 card you are at risk of 1/X of the time having it die on you. If you have 10 small cards you are risk of losing 1/10th of your pictures 1/X of the time, or differently said you are 10 TIMES as likely to lose some pictures. And given humans ability to track many small items that fall out of pockets and such it's probably way more than 10x. BUT you say, I only lose 1/10th my photos rather than all my photos! True, but big cards are cheap enough with the above amazon deal that you can have two and swap them back and forth during idle times in the action. Or cameras like 5d Mark III and canon 1D series let you write jpegs to a second card as backup which you should be doing if you're a wedding photographer and the mother in law is going to go ballistic if you lose any shots anyway.
I'm happy to go in to more detail on my reasoning and the math behind USE BIG CARDS if people are interested.
Anyway, checkout the amazon sale and have your camera pretty much always say 999 shots remaining!﻿
Meer lezen (40 regels)Minder weergeven

Does anyone have a CompactFlash card that is 2GB or smaller they don't want?
I have an old camera I want use but it's so old that the largest memory card it supports is 2GB, and the smallest cards I have are 4GB. Surprisingly you can still buy the old cards (assuming its not a stock control error) but they cost the same as cards that are four times larger and four times faster.﻿

The World's Fastest Memory Card Lexar's 3333x CFast 2.0 ratchets up the read speed of Compact Flash cards to a dizzying 500MB/s—and that is very, very fast. They'll be available in in 32GB, 64GB, 128GB and 256GB sizes. It's worth noting that you could theoretically fill up the smallest one in around a minute if you were so inclined. A minute. http://gizmodo.com/this-is-the-worlds-fastest-memory-card-for-a-little-w-1496961460?utm_campaign=socialflow_gizmodo_twitter&utm_source=gizmodo_twitter&utm_medium=socialflow﻿

Meer lezen (24 regels)Minder weergeven · Vertalen

Well, recently I've had some photography bad luck (http://bit.ly/y6FbGd), and it seems to be continuing tonight! +Trey Ratcliff and I just got home from a full day of shooting (part of which was the PhotoWalk we hosted today http://bit.ly/vZQLWz).
When I put my brand-spanking new 32GB SanDisk Compact Flash card into my card reader, nothing showed up. I couldn't import! Then we tried two other card readers laying around. Nothing. So I put the card back in my camera, and tried to view them there. I got the "Folder Contains No Images" message familiar to Nikon users.
At this point, I downloaded a program called "Card Rescue" for Mac to see if the files had somehow been corrupted or damage. Trey had successfully used this program to recover some files before. After running a scan for nearly an hour, it said it couldn't find any files. Whenever I tried to import from the card, it referred to my CF card as "JO NAMA" ... Strange name, and I have no idea where it came from.
So either someone out there has some good ideas for better card recovery software, or SanDisk is out there and they can help me, or there may be something to those ghost stories people tell about the Queen Mary. That was the last location of the evening... Me and Trey drove down to Long Beach to shoot some parts of the ship that are supposedly haunted. All in good fun you'd think, until the electromagnetic field generated by the ghosts wipe out your memory card... ! ;-) Or maybe it was the nuclear reactor on that Scorpion submarine we climbed onto?
Here's a ghostly image I caught of myself a few months ago, before my camera fell into the Ocean, before I got arrested for taking photos (another story I haven't told), and before my memory card went dead!
#LAPhotoWalk Unfortunately this means I have zero photos from the PhotoWalk, unless I can somehow get the photos back!﻿
